Award.AwardTitle: Catalytic Deoxydehydration of Biomass-Derived Polyols to Olefins

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
ABSTRACT

#1160219
P.I.: Friederike C. Jentoft

The key chemical transformations that are needed in the conversion of biomass into fungible fuels or useful chemical intermediates, such as olefins, are characterized by effectively removing oxygen ideally without significant loss of carbon. One approach would be to achieve this employing several catalytic conversion processes, allowing each to be optimized in terms of catalyst employed. Polyols, molecules with multiple OH functionalities, are easily obtainable from cellulosic biomass in known conversion processes. Principal investigators Friederike C. Jentoft and Kenneth M. Nicholas of the University of Oklahoma are proposing to develop novel, heterogeneous catalysts that will convert biomass-derived polyol substrates in liquid phase, hydrophilic media. The target reaction is a deoxydehydration, that is, oxygen and water will be removed simultaneously by reduction and dehydration, respectively. With the help of a sacrificial reducing agent, the net loss of two OH groups from the polyol can be effected, and a versatile olefinic product is obtained.

The primary objectives of this project are to develop supported oxo-metal complexes as catalysts for the deoxydehydration of polyols to olefinic products, to identify the reactive oxo-metal species involved in these processes and to elucidate the reaction mechanism. Achievement of the project?s objective will be facilitated by the synergistic interaction between the Nicholas group in the Department of Chemistry & Biochemistry and the Jentoft group in the School of Chemical, Biological and Materials Engineering. The groups combine expertise in organometallic chemistry and homogeneous catalysis with expertise in heterogeneous catalysis and spectroscopy. The PIs will explore an array of catalyst compositions, with candidate transition metals for the oxo-complexes being rhenium, molybdenum and vanadium, and candidates for supports being activated carbon, ceria, and layered double hydroxides. The catalytic activity, selectivity and stability of these materials for deoxydehydration of polyols will be tested using sulfites and molecular hydrogen as reducing agents and a variety of conditions and solvents. The key steps in the catalytic deoxydehydration processes will be elucidated by spectroscopically monitoring the interaction of deoxydehydration reductants and glycols with active supported oxo-metal complexes.

Successful execution of this research project will: 1) establish a new, potentially useful, chemical transformation of cellulosic- and glycolic feedstocks for the sustainable preparation of value-added unsaturated products and intermediates that can be further converted by existing processes; 2) provide fundamental knowledge and understanding of chemical reactions involving carbohydrate/polyol substances, supported metal-oxo species, practical reductants, and suitable reaction media; and 3) supply cutting-edge cross-disciplinary educational and technical training in the key discipline of catalysis for undergraduate and graduate students as well as for postdoctoral researchers.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project targeted the development of new solid catalysts for deoxydehydration, a chemical transformation that simultaneously removes oxygen and water from a molecule containing two neighboring OH groups (i.e., a vicinal diol), thus producing an alkene. This transformation is useful to convert biomass-derived compounds, which are rich in OH groups, into platform molecules that can be further processed to valuable chemicals or fuels. Solid catalysts are easily separable from liquid reaction media and enable a sustainable large-scale production.

There were two primary goals; to develop solid catalysts containing the known active component rhenium, and to identify new active components that are less expensive than rhenium.

The general strategy to develop rhenium-containing solid catalysts was to disperse and attach rhenium complexes on high-surface-area supports, including carbon, silicon dioxide and a number of metal oxides, all in the form of loose powders. Several strategies to affix the rhenium to the support were pursued, for example, electrostatic adsorption of perrhenate, tethering of metalorganic complexes, and intercalation into layered compounds. These new materials were characterized with spectroscopic and microscopic methods, to demonstrate high rhenium dispersion, and then tested using a variety of diol substrates and compared with benchmark catalysts, which were commercially available soluble rhenium compounds. All solid catalysts were active, and generally exhibited excellent substrate versatility and high selectivity to the desired alkene. A variety of reductants, which are stoichiometrically required for deoxydehydration, were applied in the catalytic tests and mostly found to give satisfactory results even though reaction times to reach high product yields varied significantly. Notable is the success of gaseous reductants such as hydrogen and carbon monoxide, which are available on a large scale, and of secondary alcohols. The stability of each of the supported rhenium catalysts was evaluated by repeated recovery of the solid from the liquid reaction mixture and re-use of this recovered catalyst in another test. Catalyst deactivation by rhenium leaching into the liquid phase was identified as a major issue. The main factors governing rhenium leaching were found to be the surface chemistry of the catalyst support, the solubility of the diol in the chosen solvent, and consequently, substrate conversion. With this knowledge, strategies to prevent leaching or to recover the catalyst can be devised. The findings concerning leaching and readsorption are principal in nature and have potential for broader impact, that is, they may be valid for other materials and catalytic processes.

With the goal of replacing the expensive rhenium, complexes of several other transition metals were tested for their catalytic activity in deoxydehydration. Of the tested species, several oxido-vanadium complexes were promising in a homogeneous catalysis process. In addition, heterogenized oxido-complexes of molybdenum also catalyzed deoxydehydration, but higher reaction temperatures were required than for rhenium, which led to lower alkene selectivity and more side produces. Moreover, the carbon-carbon double bond in the product alkene shifted from the terminal position to an internal position, which lowers the value of this product.

The main outcomes of this research are a number of new catalysts for deoxydehydration of vicinal diols to alkenes, based on the transition metal rhenium as the active compound, or, alternatively, the less expensive metals vanadium or molybdenum. These catalysts may be useful in the conversion of biomass-derived compounds to valuable chemicals or fuels, thus enhancing sustainability. In addition, new insight was gained into leaching of catalytically active species during liquid phase processing, which is an important and unresolved issue in multiple catalytic applications.

The project involved postdoctoral researchers, graduate students and undergraduate students, some of them from minorities or underrepresented groups. The results of this research project were the basis of one M.S. thesis and contribute to one Ph.D. thesis. A Ph.D. student from the University of Massachusetts Amherst visited the University of Oklahoma for training in catalytic measurements.

The results of this project have been disseminated within the STEM community through several publications in peer-reviewed international journals and through presentations at several regional, national and international meetings. The project theme was introduced to middle and high school students at the Oklahoma Women in Science Conference.


Last Modified: 05/03/2019
Modified by: Friederike C Jentoft
